div1.head: Memorandum from Henry Rose Carter and Joseph A. LePrince, 1916
div1.p:
PHYSICAL SURVEY FOR MOSQUITO CONTROL
OF
PROPOSED POND
AT
WHITNEY, NORTH CAROLINA.

BY
H. R. CARTER
ASSISTANT SURGEON-GENERAL
AND
J. A. LE PRINCE
SANITARY ENGINEER
OF THE
UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
1916
MEMORANDUM

PHYSICAL SURVEY FOR MOSQUITO CONTROL
OF PROPOSED POND AT WHITNEY, N.C.
By H. R. CARTER,
Assistant Surgeon-General,
and
J. A. Le PRINCE,
Sanitary Engineer,
United States Public Health Service.
Present Condition:

From conversation with Mr. Hardaway and the Assistant Warden
at the convict camp we learned that there had evidently been much
malaria in this immediate vicinity of recent years. We heard also
of this disease on the upper part of Beaver Dam Creek. Even without
this information we came across -we were not looking for them- so
considerable a number of places physically well suited for breeding
anopheles that we would have come to the same conclusion. As these
will generally be destroyed by filling the pond they will not be
especially enumerated, but there is no question that where people
are thick enough there should be considerable malaria in this country.
General Measures:

We aim to prevent or lessen the breeding of mosquitoes and
to do this by exposing their larvae (wiggle-tails) to wave action
and fish, the main agents in their destruction.

We can do little to influence wave action as it depends main-
ly on the shape of the shore. The removal of heavy drift wood,
however, will help this to some extent. To increase the action
of fish we can do this much, and at this place fish will be, in
many portions of the pond, our sole dependence against mosquitoes.

The larvae are protected against fish by small flotage next
to ar against the bank and our object is 1 to (1st) prevent its form-
ation, and (2)nd to strand it up on the bank above water. The
latter method is by far the most efficacious. Naturally all float-
Memo-2
ing material that stays in the pond for any length of time will
reach the bank unless prevented by some obstruction from doing so.
If this reaches the bank when the pond is high it will be left
stranded upon the bank when the pond falls. We must then not
allow obstructions to exist which will prevent this flotage reaching
the bank.

I will take then two datum lines,- one the 540 contour,
your ordinary maximum level, and a lower contour “X,” not left
bare more than ten consecutive days.

(1) Trees and brush completely submerged at all times are
of no importance and can be left. The same is true of such in
the pond (away from the bank) that do not reach above contour “X.”
Hardwood trees anywhere in the pond are a matter of small importance,
and need not be cut for sanitary reasons though I understand it
is proposed to do so to prevent interference with the operation
of the plant. Pine trees whose tops come above “X” should be
“ringed” (belted) or cut down this spring so that they may not cast
pine needles in the pond in the summer of 1917, and laps of trees
any where in the pond that will float up to the surface had better
be removed or destroyed.

(2) Clear the edges of the pond of brush. Taking the 540
contour go up--say--three feet above it on very steep banks and 10
or 15 ft. above it on sloping banks--measured on the surface. Cut
out all brush that will stop floatage down to the contour “X” and
below it--say--three feet on steep slopes and 10 feet on gentle
slopes. This stuff that is cut must be removed from the pond eith-
er by dragging above the clear space or by a complete burning. All
laps down in this clear space must, of course, be removed.
Memo-3

(3) When there are thick groves of hard wood sap-
lings growing at any point adjacent to the clear edge, whose
tops project above the contour “X” and are so thick as to
stop a considerable amount of drift they should be cut down
and removed. The same for the brushy tops of trees in the
same situation.

In our judgment this is all of the cutting that will
do any good as a sanitary measure, but I cannot lay too much
stress upon the necessity of removing the things out from
the pond. The stumps on the upper contours of this edge
should be cut as low as possible, because if the water covers
the stump most of the time the stump will not throw up sprouts.
If it does not, it will. It will be necessary, I think, once
or possibly twice a year for the first few years, to go over
this edge above your ordinary highwater line to cut off
the sprouts that come up.

It will not be necessary to do any of this work in
such parts of the pond as are -say- one and a quarter miles
from a residence (annoccupied house). This distance is excess
of what is deemed generally necessary, but is specified as
giving quite a factor of safety.

(4) If it be practicable, weather conditions may
prevent it, it would be a very great advantage to burn over
the pond site, the whole of it, just before it is filled &
as close to the filling as possible. This will get rid of
leaves, pine needles and small brush generally which would
otherwise rise up and float on the pond. It will also tend
Memo-4
to kill the stumps that are above high water level.

(6) With a pond in which there will be as large fluct-
uations of level as this one it will be advisable to look over
the upper contours and see if it will leave pools or small ponds as it fall
and if so to drain them by suitable ditches. Likely enough it
will be impracticable to judge of this until all parts of the pond
are filled and you see whether it does leave such pools. A pool
drained within fourteen or sixteen days of its formation does no
harm, and a pool that does not last that time, by drying up or
otherwise does no harm.

(7) Since you are depending mainly on fish for the control
of mosquito breeding in this pond we would advise you to make
arrangements for getting such fish, either this fall or at least
very early next spring, the former being prefereable.

(8) The U.S. Fish Commission has a Hatchery of mosquito
eating fish at Elizabeth City, N. C. Note that the fish that
you want are TOP MINNOWS. Game fish would be a disadvantage to
you as they would eat the minnows instead of the mosquito larvae.
The minnows are needed in large quantities.
(9) SPECIAL LOCALITIES
(Referring to property map.)

1. I do not think any of the willows here except those next to
the bank, and next to the old Whitney Dam are high enough to re-
quire attention. Those next to the bank on both sides of the
river are to be cut or removed.

2. There is a lot of debris here, old tressels etc, which
should be removed, as they will float up when the pond is low.

Can't be under-
stood without map.
Memo-5

3 & 4. The measures to be taken, clearing of the brush etc.,
are provided for in the general measures, but they should be taken
with extreme pains on account of their proximity to Whitney,
which doubtless will have considerable population. (5) The old canal
and the bights that go off from beyond the Winston-Salem railroad
will likely be a very troublesome proposition. Indeed a good part
of the bottom of this canal, especially toward the lower part,
was probably breeding profusely the last few summers. It is in
every way well fitted physically for breeding mosquitoes now.
It too will have to be cleaned with more than ordinary care,
and the edges of the bank kept clean more than is necessary for
the rest of the pond.
This place is dangerous for three reasons:-
(1) It is close to considerable villages, Palmerville and Whitney.

(2) It is so narrow that wave action will have no effect and we
will have to depend entirely upon fish.

(3) The sides are so steep-vertical -in many places- that the
fluctuations of the pond will not rid us of flotage.

The measures devised for the rest of the pond must be accen-
tuated for this canal and the bights. It must be very carefully
cleared. The bank must be kept clear of floating material -by
hand I expect,- and it must be especially stocked with fish. I believe
however, that these places in their natural condition are now
producing many anopheles.

6. Is simply marked because all along the edge of this cliff
there is a very large amount of tree laps in the woods, some
of which would float up and hence should be removed.
Memo-6

7. In the lower reaches of Bever Dam most of the stuff
will be completely submerged and needs no attention, The edges
will require cutting.

8. The upper reaches of Beaver Dam Creek and Reynolds Fork are
in quite flat country and there are a number of farm houses empty
around them. These places will probably be dangerous as they
are too narrow for wave action to do much good.
They are far less dangerous, however, than the canal.
(1) Because there are not nearly so many people.

(2) In shoal water the fish have a great deal more control of the
mosquitoes.

(3) The gentle slope of the banks allows flotage to strand, hence
we should have clean edges. An extra planting of minnows
in this locality is very advisable. Also lookout for pools
left by the falling pond.

For the convenience of anyone making a biological survey
of this place during the summer, which should be done as it would
throw much light upon its present condition in the production
of malaria breeding mosquitoes, I would enumerate suchsuchsome of those
places as seem to us physically well suited for breeding anopheles
as we have noticed. (See Numbers on Map)

1. Back of the old Whitney Office site there are a number
of pools physically well suited for breeding.

2. Behind railway fill just below Whitney, -two places
in upper part, one in lower.

3. Second bight below Whitney beyond the Winston-Salem
South-bound, a large area physically well suited for breeding.
Memo-7

4. In the valley of Beaver Dam Creek where the road
crosses it not far from the river at No. 7. A rather large area.

5. At No. 8 from the Mouth of Buffalo Creek down to
Beaver Dam and between them is a large area well suited for
production.

6. At Gladys Fork where it joins Beaver Dam the creek
spreads out into a number of pools extremely well suited
physically for breeding.

7. A small place, spring head and marshy stream, to the
rear of Elliott's house, about 200 yards off. This may dry up
in summer time.

8. At saw mill beyond Elliott's house, a large breeding
place.

9. Beyond abandoned house of J.C. Russell, a series of
pools in the woods.

10. At the crossing of Reynold's Fork beyond a saw mill,
and at the crossing of the last fork of Beaver Dam Creek where
the land is very flat are several large areas (2 places).

11. At two crossings of Reynold's Fork going back towards
the Yadkin, several pools on the side of the road in the woods, on
the uplands, going towards the Yadkin; one place, in cat tails,
in the race of the power plant, (several places)

It is not pretended that these are all, or even any con-
siderable portion of the breeding places in the area to be cover-
ed by the pond; they are simply some that we noted as we passed
along a part of its periphery.
Memo-8
CARE OF THE POND AFTER IT IS FILLED.

1. Keep the winter level of the pond from October first
to June 15th or 30th as high as possible, so as to strandthat all
of the flotage that comes to the banks at this time of the year
maybe stranded when the pond falls towards the summer level.

2. Save the summer floods, July 1st to October 1st, as
much as you can so as to have the pond level fluctuate during
this season. It is understood that the summer level is less,
by some feet, than the normal winter level. The pond should not
be kept up during the summer time into the line of already stranded
drift for as long a time as three weeks, preferably not over two
weeks. It will generally be impossible to do this, even if you
wish it.

3. For the first few years we judge it will ne necessary
to cut down the sprouts that will come up above your 540 contour.
Below that contour it should be kept clean of living growth by
the pond itself.

4. The edge of the pond should be examined between July
1st and October 1st so that collections of logs and heavy drift
that may possibly land against the bank, and yet be floating,
can be dragged out. This will possiblyprobably not be necessary after
the first year or two.

If collections of small flotage are seen resting against the
bank they should be dragged out. The banks of the canal and itsthe
bights from Whitney down should be given very special attention
in this respect and will, we fear, require much attention.
It all depends upon how efficacious the fish will prove here.
Memo-9

Nothing is advised to prevent the growth of aquatic plants which
in the future may be a problem. This condition will have to be
met when it arises, if it does arise. We do not know enough of
this as yet to advise general manoeuvres in advance.

The measures we have indicated above are about all that are
applicable for the control of mosquitoee (Anopheles) production
by this pond within allowable economic limits. They are in excess
of what we would feel justified in requiring, but are as specified
for the following reasons:-

(1) The very considerable number of people who will be ad-
jacent to the pond at Whitney, Palmersville and Badin.

(2) The unusual risk of mosquito production entailed by
the canal and the bights behind the Winston Salem R. R. track.

(3) The statement that you were prepared to carry out all
measures which would do good at any reasonable expense.

Even with these measures carried out it is not pretended
that there will be no anopheles production from the pond. There
will be. The total production of the pond site will likely be
no greater, or less, than at present, but the location of breeding
will be changed, and malaria may be increased in some places.
The measures advised should, however, minimize mosquito production
and this with proper screening, and possibly the use of quinine
should minimize the malaria in the community.

It must be noted that the increase in population adjacent
to the canal would increase the number of malaria cases among them,
even with no change in the condition of breeding places. This
increase will be out of proportion to the increase of population,
rather as a function of the square, or possibly of the third power
Memo-10
of that increase, and this must be discounted in estimating the
malaria due directly to mosquitoes produced by the pond. It
will be the more noticeable as people come in from non-malarious
communities.

H. R. Carter
Asst. Surgeon-General
U. S. P. H. S.

J. A. Le Prince
Sanitary engineer
U. S. P. H. S.
